Award.AwardTitle: DDIG: Assessment of fighting ability and the use of the aggressive call in gray treefrog contests
Award.AbstractNarration:
In many animals, aggressive signals, rather than overt physical fighting are used to resolve disputes. Despite intensive research into aggressive signaling, the means by which most animals assess their own status and that of competitors during contests remains unclear: for example, animals may use mutual assessment, in which persistence in a contest is based on assessing their fighting ability relative to that of their opponent, or they may use self-assessment, in which the decision to withdraw is based only on assessing their own accumulated costs, regardless of characteristics of their opponent. Recent theoretical work has provided a method to distinguish between possible means of assessment. This study will use these recent theoretical advances to determine whether male gray treefrogs, Hyla versicolor, use mutual or self assessment during aggressive vocal interactions. Measurements of the duration and level of escalation of staged aggressive encounters between calling males in size-equal and size-unequal pairings will be used to distinguish between these two possibilities. Under mutual assessment, contests are expected to be longer when individuals are more closely matched, regardless of their absolute size, while self-assessment predicts that contest duration is an increasing function of the absolute size of the smaller individual, regardless of size asymmetry.

This experiment will provide important new information on the significance of aggressive signaling that will be important for confirming the results of recent theoretical work. It will also continue the development of H. versicolor as a model for studies of aggressive signaling. Aggressive calling in frogs has been understudied in general, yet frogs offer many advantages to the study of communication. Finally, this project will provide important research experiences for several undergraduate students (including those from underrepresented groups), who will be given the opportunity to participate fully in the project's execution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aggressive behavior in animals is very important in their lives: it helps determine who gets access to mates, food and other resources. Even though it is so critical to an individual’s success, in many animals most disputes are settled with signals, without resorting to violent physical fighting. Why this is so has long been puzzling for scientists that study animal behavior. Even more puzzling is how animals use these signals to determine their behavior in contests. What characteristics of aggressive signals determine which individuals persist or withdraw from the contest, and why are these particular characteristics more important than others? We studied these questions by developing a new method to observe aggressive interactions in the gray treefrog. Frogs are important species for studies of signaling because they produce very loud calls during the mating season.

We first looked at how body size determines success in competition. In many animals, larger males tend to be more likely to win and individuals may assess one another’s body size in determining for how long they should attempt to win the contest. However, we found that larger males did not have a very strong advantage in gray treefrogs. There was also no evidence that larger individuals tended to persist longer in contests or that individuals gave up more quickly when faced with a larger opponent. However, we did find evidence that the aggressive calls that males make when competing with one another may play an important role. Males lowered the frequency, or pitch, of their aggressive calls when compared to the calls they use to attract mates. Furthermore, males could lower this frequency even further as the competition became more escalated. We think that males are likely to pay attention to their opponent’s call frequency which may signal something about its general quality as a competitor. For example, individuals that can give very low frequency calls might have more energy available for calling.

 

Competition changed other calling behaviors as well. Males tended to change their advertisement calls, the calls they normally use to attract females. When males were competing with one another at very close range they often increased the duration of these calls as well as the rate at which they called. This is certainly very energetically challenging and we found that males were limited in how intensely they could call under these circumstances. At the same time males competing with each other were more likely to overlap their opponent’s calls with calls of their own. This call overlap may be part of the early interactions that lead to full-blown aggressive signaling and physical fighting.

 

In general these experiments showed that frogs exhibit many interesting behaviors under extreme competition. We now understand much more about their communication system and about the lives of animals in general that are faced with competition from other nearby individuals. This has important implications for what we know about how animals use signals in different circumstances and the types of strategies that are available to deal with a complicated social environment. These findings are significant contributions to the understanding of animal behavior and evolution.
